A conversation JT and I have a lot with people who are in their sort of mid to late 30s, maybe even early 40s,
and who come from a background of strength training. So these are people who have sort of lifted weights
for a long time, whether it's barbell work or bodybuilding, and they've found Jiu Jitsu and you know,
whatever, they've got this background and they're now at a point where they really want to get back
to where they were. So it's like I want to get back to being the Jacked 27-year-old and I want to
change Jiu Jitsu. There's a couple of really important things that we've got to think about here.
So the first thing is, is that you are not what you were, right? So your body has changed. I'm not saying
it gets worse or it gets better. It just changes, right? So in terms of your recovery, in terms of
your ability to operate on fuck all sleep, in terms of your ability to extract a reasonable amount
of nutrition from terrible foods, those things maybe you don't have those freedoms anymore. So
that's the first part we've got to acknowledge. The second part is that you've got to
sell the shit going on in your life. So you're usually working a lot more, maybe you've got your
own business, you might have kids, you might have a partner, you've got other obligations that are
competing, right? With your desire to get to the gym and to get to bed early and to eat fucking
six meals a day and whatever it is. So the problem is, is that this mindset of I need to get back to
training five days a week on the barbell and I want to train three or five days a week of
jiu-jitsu as well and I'll be the jacked 25 year old that I was at 35 or 45. It's bullshit, it's not
going to happen. I'm not saying this to make you depressed, but I'm saying this to make you realize
that it's a very sort of limited mindset to think that what got you to where you were is what
will get you to the next point because you are not the same person and your circumstances are not
the same. So this is a really a recurring thing amongst people who come from that strength background
where training is a huge part of their life and like a lot of the second day I had this myself,
you go through this stage and your 20s and only 30s are very absolute savage and it doesn't
matter what you do, you're just getting stronger and making more gains and choking more fools and
whatever. And then you hit this point where you maybe start getting injured, start getting little
niggles, stuff to put on a little bit of weight, you know the numbers are going down on the dead
left and stuff and I guess what I'm saying is you've got to change your fucking mindset, you have
to change your mentality around training, you've got to understand that if you really do like
Jiu-Jitsu and that's your main thing then that's the thing you should focus on and your strength training
should be supplementary to that. This is really why our program is built around two to three days
of strength training a week because in reality most people don't have the time to go to the gym
five nights a week and so if you're kind of trying to squeeze this sort of square peg into a round
hole and you're like I got to get in, I got to do my five by five, I've got to do my fucking five
three one or German volume training whatever the fuck you got to try and snap out of that because
I'm not saying that you can't be more jacked than you were at 25, I'm not saying you can't be
leaner than you were at 25 and I'm definitely not saying that you can't be more mobile and move
better than you ever have before. It's the process that you're going to take to get you there
that's going to be different this time round.
